questions.text: Which of the following is the most potent vasoconstrictor?
questions.solution: The most potent vasoconstrictor is urotensin2 followed by endothelin and angiotensin.

questions.text: Which of the following is a component of δ granules of platelets?
questions.solution:
Epinephrine is a component of δ granules of platelets.

The different components of platelet granules are: 

  •  α granules 
    • Fibrinogen
    • Fibronectin
    • PF4
    • Factor V, VIII 
    • PDGF
    • TGF
  •  δ granules 
    • ADP
    • Calcium
    • Serotonin
    • Histamine
    • Epinephrine

questions.text: Rees and Ecker diluting fluid is used in ______
questions.solution:
Rees and Ecker's solution is used as a diluting fluid in the RBC pipette for performing platelet counts. Its composition is:

Components Value
Sodium citrate 3.8 g
Formaldehyde (40 %) 0.2 ml
Brilliant cresyl blue 0.1 g
Distilled water 100 ml

The steps involved in platelet count are:

I - Filling the pipette

  • Diluting fluid is drawn to mark 1 of the RBC pipette and expelled
  • Blood is aspirated to 0.5 mark of the RBCs diluting pipette
  • Diluting fluid is aspirated to 101 mark
  • Blood and diluting fluid are mixed mechanically for 5 min

II - Filling the counting chamber

  • Allow the counting chamber to stand for 20-30 minutes to allow the platelets to settle.
  • To prevent drying out of the preparation, it should be kept in a moist atmosphere, this is most easily arranged by placing the filled counting chamber in the bottom of a clean Petri dish, alongside which arrange a small piece of cotton wool which has been soaked in water and squeezed out. Petri dish lid is additionally put over the dish.
  • After 20-30minutes, the counting chamber can be removed and carefully transferred to the microscope stage.

III - Counting the number of platelets

  • Focus on the surface of the hemocytometer chamber with a high power dry objective. Dim the light to make the thrombocytes visible, and count all of the thrombocytes in the entire center 1 mm² (erythrocyte counting area) of both sides of the hemocytometer. This gives the number of thrombocytes in 0.2 l of 1: 200 dilution of blood.
  • The number of thrombocytes counted X 1000 = number of thrombocytes/l of undiluted blood.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl with dengue hemorrhagic fever is being monitored by measuring platelet count. Spontaneous bleeding is associated with platelet values below _______ /µL.
questions.solution:
Spontaneous bleeding (non-traumatic) is associated with platelet values below 20,000 platelets/µL.

It most often involves small vessels. The common sites for such hemorrhages are:

  • Skin
  • Mucosa of gastrointestinal and genitourinary tracts
  • Intracranial bleeding - most feared site of bleeding

The production of the platelets is regulated by the hormone thrombopoietin produced in the liver. The platelet synthesis is also specifically increased by interleukin 6. The average lifespan of the platelets is 7–10 days. The normal platelet count is 1,50,000 - 4,00,000 /µL.

Related Pearl: Causes of Thrombocytopenia

I. Decreased Production of Platelets

  1. Selective impairment of platelet production
    • Drug-induced: alcohol, thiazides, cytotoxic drugs
    • Infections: measles, human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
  2. Nutritional deficiencies - B12, folate deficiency
  3. Bone marrow failure - aplastic anemia
  4. Bone marrow replacement - leukemia, disseminated cancer, granulomatous disease
  5. Ineffective hematopoiesis - myelodysplastic syndromes 

II. Decreased Platelet Survival

  1. Immunologic destruction
    • Primary autoimmune - chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura, acute immune thrombocytopenic purpura
    • Secondary autoimmune - systemic lupus erythematosus, B-cell lymphoid neoplasms
    • Alloimmune - posttransfusion and neonatal
    • Drug-associated - quinidine, heparin, sulfa compounds
    • Infections - HIV, infectious mononucleosis (transient, mild), dengue fever
  2. Nonimmunologic destruction
    • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
    • Thrombotic microangiopathies
    • Giant hemangiomas

III. Sequestration - The spleen normally sequesters 30% to 35% of platelets. This can rise to 80% to 90% when the spleen is enlarged, producing moderate degrees of thrombocytopenia.

IV. Dilution - Transfusions

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding functional platelet disorders?

choices.text: Normal platelet count and normal bleeding time
Normal platelet count and increased bleeding time
Decreased platelet count and increased bleeding time
Decreased platelet count and decreased bleeding time

questions.solution:
Functional platelet disorders have normal platelet count and increased bleeding time. 

Classification of platelet functional disorders:

  • Defect in platelet-vessel wall interaction (disorders of adhesion)
    • Von Willebrand disease - deficiency or defect in plasma vWF
    • Bernard–Soulier syndrome - deficiency or defect in GP Ib IX
  • Defects in platelet-platelet interaction (disorders of aggregation)
    • Congenital afibrinogenemia - deficiency of plasma fibrinogen
    • Glanzmann thrombasthenia - deficiency or defect in GPIIb-IIIa
  • Disorders of platelet secretion and signal transduction
    • Storage pool deficiency - α-Granule deficiency and gamma-Granule deficiency
    • Quebec platelet disorder
    • Chediak–Higashi syndrome
    • Gray platelet syndrome
    • Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome
  • Disorders of platelet coagulation-protein interaction
    • Scott syndrome - defect in factor Va-Xa interaction on platelets

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about vonWillebrand factor?

choices.text: Its deficiency can also cause factor VIII defect
Its deficiency may cause defective platelet adhesion
It serves as a carrier for factor VIII

questions.solution:
Von Willebrand factor (vWF) is not synthesized by hepatocytes. They are produced by endothelial cells of liver and megakaryocytes. It is also found in:

  • Platelet granules - lesser compared to endothelial cells
  • Endothelial cells within cytoplasmic vesicles called Weibel-Palade bodies
  • Subendothelium - binds to collagen

It mediates the adhesion of platelets to sites of vascular injury (subendothelium). It links the exposed collagen to platelets. It facilitates platelet to platelet interaction and also stabilizes the hemostatic plug against shear forces. 

It is a carrier protein for factor VIII and also protects it from proteolytic degradation and stabilizes it. The half-life of factor VIII is about 2.4 hours when free and 12 hours when bound to vWF in the circulation.

Since vWF stabilizes factor VIII, a deficiency of vWF gives rise to a secondary decrease in factor VIII levels. This may be reflected by a prolongation of the partial thromboplastin time (PTT) in von Willebrand disease types 1 and 3.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman is found to have uncontrolled bleeding after a minor cut injury. Her lab investigations are given below. Which of the following statements are false about her condition?

Platelet count - 4,60,000 /μL

Bleeding time - increased

PT - normal

APTT - increased

choices.text: Type 3 is inherited as autosomal dominant

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of von Willebrand disease (vWD). Type 3 vWD is inherited as an autosomal recessive disease. 

The characteristics of different subtypes of vWD are:

Subtype

Description

Inheritance

Lab findings

Type 1

Quantitative deficiency of vWF

Autosomal dominant

Reduced vWF antigen, activity and Factor VIII

Type 2

Qualitative defect in vWF

Autosomal dominant

Reduced vWF activity to antigen ration<0.6

Type 3

Near-complete (quantitative) deficiency of Factor VIII

Autosomal recessive

Marked reduction or absence in Factor VIII levels

Type 1 is the most common subtype of vWD. In Type 2, vWF is expressed in normal amounts, but missense mutations are present that lead to defective multimer assembly. This type has several subtypes, of which type 2A is the most common.

Laboratory findings in vWD:

  • Prolonged bleeding time
  • Normal platelet count
  • Hess test - positive tourniquet test due to defective platelet adhesion 
  • Ristocetin-induced aggregation - defective and diagnostic of this disease
  • Platelet aggregation with ADP, collagen, and thrombin - normal
  • Increased aPTT

Though the synthesis of factor VIII remains normal, the half-life of VIII in plasma decreases due to reduced vWF (carrier) levels. This leads to secondary VIIIC deficiency in plasma. So, the intrinsic pathway of coagulation is affected. Hence, aPTT is increased in these patients.

questions.text: Which of the following occurs due to a defect in δ granules of the platelets?
questions.solution:
Hermansky–Pudlak syndrome occurs due to a defect in platelet δ granules.

Platelet granules disorders include: 

  • Gray platelet syndrome - involves α granules and characterized by thrombocytopenia with large platelets that appear pale on the peripheral smear (due to deficiency of the α granules)
  • Quebec platelet syndrome - defect in α granules 
  • Hermansky–Pudlak syndrome - defect in δ granules and characterized by hypopigmentation and bleeding manifestation
  • Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome - mutations in the WASp gene expressed in the X chromosome and characterized by microthrombocytopenia, eczema, recurrent infections

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about Bernard-Soulier syndrome?

choices.text: There is defective adhesion of platelets to sub-endothelial matrix
Deficiency of the platelet membrane glycoprotein complex Ib-IX is seen
Platelet aggregation by ristocetin is normal
It has an autosomal recessive inheritance

questions.solution:
In Bernard–Soulier syndrome, platelet aggregation by ristocetin is abnormal.

The receptor for vWF i.e. Ib-IX is essential for normal platelet adhesion to the subendothelial extracellular matrix. In this condition, there is deficiency of Gp Ib/ IX. Clinical manifestations include epistaxis, ecchymoses, menorrhagia, gingival bleeding, and gastrointestinal bleeding.

Laboratory findings seen in Bernard-Soulier syndrome:

  • Prolonged bleeding time
  • Moderate thrombocytopenia
  • Platelet aggregation by ristocetin is deficient (but ADP, arachidonic acid, epinephrine, collagen - normal).
  • Clot retraction - normal
  • Abnormally large platelets

The image given below shows the abnormally large platelets on peripheral smear seen in Bernard-Soulier syndrome.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old girl with a history of easy bruising was referred for further evaluation. Her previous lab reports showed that platelet count and morphology were normal. Platelet aggregations tests are given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
Agonist used Aggregation
ADP Absent
Epinephrine Absent
Collagen Absent
Ristocetin Normal
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Glanzmann thrombasthenia.

It is an abnormality of platelet GPIIb-IIIa (fibrinogen receptor). Platelets are unable to adhere to each other and to the underlying tissue of the damaged blood vessels. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. The symptoms include mucocutaneous bleeding in the neonatal period, menorrhagia, ecchymoses, epistaxis, and gingival hemorrhage.

Types of Glanzmann thrombasthenia include:

  • Type 1: Absence of GPIIb-IIIa
  • Type 2: Reduced surface expression of GPIIb-IIIa/ Essentialis athrombia - clot retraction is normal
  • Type 3: Dysfunction of GPIIb-IIIa

Laboratory features of Glanzmann thrombasthenia:

  • Normal platelet count and morphology
  • Platelet aggregation occurs in response to ristocetin, but not to other agonists (such as ADP, thrombin, collagen or epinephrine)
  • Clot retraction is absent

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy is brought with a history of recurrent impetigo. Physical examination findings are given below. Platelet counts are low and peripheral smear shows abnormally small-sized platelets. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome (WAS). The given image shows (A) multiple petechiae over face and hematoma under the right eye and (B) eczema of the foot. 

This syndrome is an X-linked recessive, primary immunodeficiency disorder involving the WAS gene. It is characterised by the triad of:

  • Severe eczema
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Recurrent infections

Small platelets are seen in:

  • Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome
  • X-linked thrombocytopenia

Large platelets are seen in:

  • Bernard-Soulier syndrome
  • Myeloproliferative syndrome
  • Myelodysplastic syndrome
  • May–Hegglin anomaly
  • Gray platelet syndrome

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents with epistaxis, easy bruising and menorrhagia. There is no history of drug intake. Physical examination shows scattered petechiae and a normal-sized spleen. Her lab investigations are given below. Antibodies against which of the following can lead to this condition?

Platelet count - 37,000/μL

Bleeding time - 16 minutes

PT - 13 seconds

aPTT - 30 seconds

Peripheral blood smear - megathrombocytes
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). Autoantibodies seen in ITP are most often directed against platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb-IIIa or Ib-IX. It is a diagnosis of exclusion due to the following findings:

  • Bleeding tendency - petechiae
  • Low platelet count, elevated bleeding time
  • Presence of megathrombocytes in the peripheral smear - a sign of accelerated thrombopoiesis
  • Female preponderance
  • Absence of splenomegaly

 Note: Prothrombin time (PT) is normal in ITP.

questions.text: Which class of antiplatelet antibodies are seen in patients with chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura?
questions.solution:
Antiplatelet antibodies in chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) are mainly IgG class.

Autoantibodies most often directed against platelet membrane glycoproteins are IIb-IIIa or Ib-IX. It can be demonstrated in the plasma and bound to the platelet surface in about 80% of patients.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman is diagnosed to have idiopathic ITP. Which of the following features is least likely to be seen in her?
questions.solution:
Lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly are uncommon in idiopathic (primary) ITP. They are seen in secondary ITP.

Chronic ITP occurs most commonly in adult women younger than 40 years of age. The female-to-male ratio is 3: 1. It is a type II hypersensitivity reaction. It is of 2 types:

  • Primary or idiopathic - without any risk factors
  • Secondary - presence of predisposing conditions like SLE, HIV, CLL

Signs of accelerated thrombopoiesis that are seen in this condition are:

  • Megakaryocytes in bone marrow
  • Megathrombocytes (abnormally large platelets) in peripheral blood

The image given below shows 2 megakaryocytes seen in bone marrow aspirate (Wrights stain).

Acute ITP is mainly a disease of childhood. It occurs with equal frequency in both sexes, mostly after a viral illness. It is self-limited condition, resolves within 6 months.

questions.text:
Patients with which of the following predisposing conditions are likely to develop chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura?
  1. Systemic lupus erythematosus
  2. HIV infection
  3. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia 
  4. Rheumatoid arthritis
  5. Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome
questions.solution:
Systemic lupus erythematosus, HIV infection, chronic lymphocytic leukemia, antiphospholipid antibody syndrome can predispose to the development of secondary immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP).

The predisposing conditions of secondary chronic ITP include:

  • Autoimmune conditions
    • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
    • Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APS)
    • Immune thyroid disease
    • Evans syndrome
  • Lymphoproliferative diseases
    • Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
    • Large granular T-lymphocyte lymphocytic leukemia
  • Chronic infection
    • Helicobacter pylori
    • Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
    • Hepatitis C virus (HCV)

questions.text:
A 63-year-old man with moderate COVID pneumonia developed DVT. Therapeutic anticoagulation with heparin was started. His lab investigations are given below. Which of the following is false about this condition?
Timing Platelet count
Before heparin therapy 3,50,000 /μL
Day 3 of therapy 3,20,000 /μL
Day 7 of therapy 53,000 /μL

choices.text: Lesser incidence with use of LMWH

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of type II heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). It is not self-resolving.

Thrombocytopenia occurs in about 5% of persons receiving heparin and is of two types:

Feature Type I Type II
Incidence More common Less common
Occurrence  Rapidly after onset of therapy 5 to 14 days after therapy
Pathogenesis Direct platelet-aggregating effect of heparin Antibodies against heparin-platelet factor 4 complexes
Severity Less severe Often leads to life-threatening venous and arterial thrombosis
Treatment Self-resolving

Immediate discontinuation of heparin

Alternate non-heparin anticoagulant to be used

questions.text: All of the following commonly cause drug-induced thrombocytopenia except _____
questions.solution:
Terlipressin does not cause drug-induced thrombocytopenia.

Drug-induced thrombocytopenia can be caused by:

  • Vancomycin
  • Quinine 
  • Rifampin

They cause thrombocytopenia through direct effects on platelets or secondary to immunologically mediated platelet destructions. Quinine, quinidine, and vancomycin bind to platelet glycoprotein and create antigenic determinants that are recognized by antibodies.

questions.text: A post-operative patient was started on prophylactic unfractionated heparin for DVT. Which of the following is false regarding this drug?

choices.text: It is an indirect thrombin-factor Xa inhibitor
It is safe in patients with renal impairment
On development of HIT, LMWH can be started alternately

questions.solution:
The risk of severe heparin-induced thrombocytopenia is lowered with LMWH but not eliminated. Hence, once severe HIT develops even LMWH exacerbates the thrombotic tendency and must be avoided.

Management of HIT includes the immediate withdrawal of heparin therapy and instituting an alternative non-heparin anticoagulant.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions is associated with ADAMTS13 deficiency?
questions.solution:
ADAMTS13 deficiency is associated with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).

ADAMTS13 is also called vWF metalloprotease which degrades very high-molecular-weight multimers of von Willebrand factor (vWF). Its deficiency causes accumulation of these multimers in the plasma and promotes platelet activation and aggregation.

TTP is a part of a spectrum of clinical syndromes called thrombotic microangiopathy. They are caused by insults that lead to excessive activation of platelets, which deposit as thrombi in small blood vessels.

Features of TTP include:

  • Fever
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia
  • Transient neurologic deficits
  • Renal failure

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought with complaints of hematuria and melena for 10 days. Laboratory investigations reveal mild thrombocytopenia and normal coagulation tests. Peripheral smear is given below. Which organism is most frequently involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing helmet cells or schistocytes are suggestive of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). This condition is most commonly associated with enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli strain O157: H7 worldwide.

This strain releases Shiga-like toxin. This toxin is absorbed from the inflamed gastrointestinal mucosa into the circulation and causes endothelial dysfunction. It leads to platelet activation and aggregation. Children and older adults are at the highest risk.

The image given below shows schistocytes or helmet cells seen in HUS.

questions.text: Deficiency of which of the following complement components is not associated with atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome is not associated with deficiency of CD59.

It is associated with deficiency of the following components:

  • Complement factor H
  • Membrane cofactor protein (CD46)
  • Complement factor I

These three proteins prevent excessive activation of the alternative complement pathway.

Deficiencies of these proteins can be caused by inherited defects or acquired inhibitory autoantibodies. The disease may be associated with a remitting, relapsing course.

questions.text: Coombs test is found to be positive in a patient with thrombocytopenia. Which of the following conditions could be a likely cause?
questions.solution:
Coombs test is positive in immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) as it is an immunogenic cause of thrombocytopenia.

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) are nonimmunogenic causes. Hence, Coombs test is negative in these conditions.

questions.text: Which of the following is affected in patients with Weber-Osler-Rendu syndrome?
questions.solution:
Weber–Osler–Rendu syndrome is a disorder of the blood vessels.

It is an autosomal-dominant disorder caused by mutations that modulate TGF-β signalling. It is also known as hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia. 

This condition is characterized by dilated, tortuous blood vessels with thin walls that bleed readily. Bleeding is most common in the mucous membranes of the nose (epistaxis), tongue, mouth, and eyes, and throughout the gastrointestinal tract.

Platelet count, prothrombin time (PT), and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) are normal.

Clinical conditions in which abnormalities of vessel wall cause bleeding include:

  • Infections - meningococcemia, infective endocarditis, rickettsioses
  • Collagen defects - Ehlers–Danlos syndrome, scurvy, and Cushing's syndrome
  • Perivascular amyloidosis - most common with amyloid light-chain (AL) amyloidosis
  • Henoch–Schönlein purpura
  • Drug reactions
